column4: hi all, is there a way to move all mp3 files from many subfolders of folderA (FolderA/subfolder1-2-3-4-...) to a unique folderB?
I'd use 'find' and 'exec'
i'll check
ok, uhm what's exec?
no manual in console for it
something like: 'find -name '*.mp3' exec mv '{}' /home/wherever /;' if i remember
'-exec' srry
can you paste the command that you typed in here?
use:  find -name '*.mp3' -exec mv '{}' /home/fabio/Musica/n/ /;
could take some time if you have alot of files though
: so it move all files from wherever to root?
: so it move all files from Musica/n/ to root?
if you know the top level folder of the mp3 files use this:  find /top/level/dir/ -name '*.mp3' -exec mv '{}' /home/fabio/Musica/n/ /;
: I actually am inside the top level folder
k, then just use:  find -name '*.mp3' -exec mv '{}' /home/fabio/Musica/n/ /;
or:  'find -name '*.mp3' -exec cp '{}' /home/fabio/Musica/n/ /;' if you want to copy rather than move the files
it says no files or dir
all files are inside subfolders
isn't it recursive on those folders?
i dont think that 'find' has a -r option if i remember
ouch
no, i mean that it dosent need a -f option, its always recursive
-r, srry
ah, i see
but still it didn't see any files :(
try just entering 'find -name '*.mp3' and check the output
WTF? strange: it listed a lot of hidden folders in which there are some mp3 files but not the actual seeable folders!!!
k, are all the mp3s you need to move in your home folder?
they are in /home/fabio/Musica
'find ~/fabio/Musica/ -name '*.mp3' and check the output
'find ~/Musica/ -name '*.mp3' srry
that should just give you a list of all the mp3s in your 'musica' folder
correct but not all files were shown
should I use *.**3?
are you sure that they are all mp3 files?
ok using *.**3 worked i think
now i do the same find thing?
cool, then try: 'find ~/Musica/ -name '*.*3' -exec cp '{}' /NEW/FOLDER/ \;
that should copy them all to the new folder
it still seems to not see those mp3s
did it copy any of them to the new folder?
noone
do you get an output of all the files you need when you: find ~/Musica/ -name '*.*3'
yes
what folder are you moving them to?
does the folder exist yet?
waht output do you get for ]: find ~/Musica/ -name '*.*3'
arf, pressed enter too early, dont enter that
a list of all files inside Musica and its subfolders
whats the output for: find ~/Musica/ -name '*.*3' -exec cp '{}' ~/m/ \;
bash: find /home/fabio/Musica/ -name *.*3 -exec mv {} /home/fabio/m/ \;: No such file or directory
replace {} with '{}'
in the bash it has ''
Hmm... If the ',
Hmm... If the 'm' folder exists, that should work...
infact if i do "find" on that folder i see all my files!!!
just, it can't move them :(
have you tried to sudo the command?
try: find ~/Musica -name '*.*3' -exec echo cp '{}' ~/m ';'
it's the same :(
that last command should outputt all the 'cp' attempts
it listed not all files copy attempts
copy one of the attempts here plz
I can't understand what's wrong really
cp /home/fabio/Musica/UNKNOWN/UNKNOWN/Io carlo - figlio dei manga.mp3 /home/fabio/m
Could it be bc of the spaces in folders/files names?
try a 'mkdir ~/m' just to be sure
uhm maybe then it's that the problem
did you try 'mkdir ~/m'
impossible tocreate
already existing file
hmmm
hmmm
just tried the command on my system and it worked fine... I'm pretty much stumped...
yeah but does it still work if the folder already exists?
it should. Give me a min, I'll just check the man for it
ty
OK, navigate to your Musica folder with: cd ~/Musica
done
and try: find -name '*.*3' -exec cp '{}' ~/m/ \;
if it's working, it could take a while
it's running, let's see
can I count how many files a folder contain?
open your home in nautilus, and click on the folder. it sould say at the bottom how many files are in it
yes sry i explained myself bad: i see the new folder has 63 items, but in the old folder (which has a lot of subfolders) says it has 236 item, but i don't know how many of them are folders
I think that 'ls -lr | wc -l' will recursively count all the files, I could be wrong though
uhm it says 32, :)
well, I'm stumped then
me too, :( thanks btw!!!
np, check out this tutorial, see if it'll help: http://www.softpanorama.org/Tools/Find/using_exec_option_and_xargs_in_find.shtml
i'll do thanks!
